subtitle: Thinking Allowed Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge
and discovery with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today we'll be exploring the fear of psychic power
or psychic functioning or psi, as parapsychologists
call it.
With me is Professor Charles Tart, who is
Emeritus Professor at the University of California
Davis and also Emeritus Professor at the Institute of Transpersonal Psychology.
Dr. Tart is the author of over 100 papers on
parapsychology and numerous books including
Open Mind, Discriminating Mind, Psi, Scientific
Studies in the Psychic Realm, Waking Up and
of course the classic anthology, Altered States of Consciousness.
Welcome again, Charlie.
Good to be here, Jeff.
It's a pleasure to be with you.
It truly is.
I don't know how much of a pleasure it's going to be to talk about fear of psi.
I hate fear myself, but we'll see.
Well, the interesting thing about fear of psi
is that many people, even in the parapsychology
community, are in denial that there is such a thing as fear of psi, and yet we live in
a culture in which people were a few hundred
years ago burnt at the stake for ostensible
psychic powers.
It is funny if you think about it historically
because the human race has always believed
that some people have malevolent psychic abilities,
and if you could hire them to work on you
side, that may be socially acceptable, but the very idea of having them out there, you
get hysterical mob reactions every once in a while, some old lady gets burned because
she looks funny, and yet somehow we're now at
a rational stage of society where we consider
such thoughts crazy and nonsensical.
One of my former mentors, who you probably remember, Arthur M. Young, used to say that
the archetype, the epitome of a paradigm shift
is witchcraft, where one era we say witches
must be burnt at the stake and the next era we say, oh, witchcraft doesn't exist.
That's quite a shift, and of course it's not
uniform, and I think the reality is that there's
still a lot of fear about it.
Most of which is dealt with by never thinking
about it, a common human way of handling problems.
Well, I know as a parapsychologist, and I'm
sure you've had the same experience, I think
everyone in parapsychology probably has, where we
give a lecture and somebody comes up afterwards
and they preface their remarks by saying, I have never told this to anyone before.
I've heard that line.
I have never told this to anyone, but let me tell you, I need to talk to somebody.
The most interesting versions of that have been people who've come up to me and saying
that, and they're scientists, sometimes prominent
scientists, and they would never mention it
to any of their scientist colleagues because
they would be considered crazy or, you know,
getting senile or something like that.
That's why I started this website, the Archives
of Scientists Transcendent Experiences, to
give them a place to express psychic and spiritual
experiences that were out of the ordinary.
That turned out to be a very interesting project
because I figured, okay, a lot of these people
need to get it off their chest somehow, but they're sensible enough to realize it's not
socially acceptable.
So I set up the website so people who were scientists could write me and I'd know who
they were, but then they could post their experience anonymously.
Well, while I ran the website, I closed it down eventually for lack of time to keep it
up, but while I ran it, about half of them
chose to be anonymous and the other half didn't.
But it was interesting, the ones who were
okay with using their real names were almost
completely scientists who'd retired and didn't
have to worry anymore about what their colleagues
thought.
So the taboo against thinking something psychic happens can still be very strong.
And very real.
I mean, scientists will lose prestige, sometimes
their positions, often their funding, simply
for being publicly associated with parapsychology.
We know the example, for instance, of Nobel Prize winner Brian Josephson, who expressed
an interest in parapsychological things and finds
stuff like he gets uninvited to conferences,
which he was originally going to be a star
speaker at, because he's associated with the
paranormal.
Really, this is weird unscientific behavior.
So there is a sense in which the social stigma
around parapsychology is not so different
than social stigmas associated with sexual deviancy or racial stigmas or all sorts of
other social prejudices.
In fact, I think most of the others are being addressed now.
We see the legalization of gay marriage, but
parapsychology hasn't yet achieved the kind
of social leverage where we get to have a large-scale addressing of that fear.
I used to commute to work in a carpool with a
lot of women faculty members, and of course,
they were very much into feminism and the
politics of it, and I used to tease them sometimes
thinking, I'm a member of a minority, too,
that gets unfairly persecuted, but we're such
a small minority, we don't have any leverage.
Well, so the fear of being persecuted is a real fear.
Fear of going insane or being insane or being
thought of as insane, well, that might be
real, but I don't know of very many people who have gone insane because they took an
interest in parapsychology.
Where would we find any statistics on it?
I do know that certainly a lot of people who
have admitted to having psychic and spiritual
experiences have been treated very badly.
They've been referred to psychiatrists, some
of them have actually been committed just
because they had an unusual experience, and so it must be a sign of craziness.
I know I've ended up being a sort of a therapist
to some of those people, even though that
wasn't part of my life plan.
I started training in clinical psychology in
graduate school because I thought it would be hard
to make a living with my interests, but there
was plenty of need for therapists, but I gave
it up after a while thinking, I don't have enough emotional intelligence.
And I know the tests and stuff we had back
then weren't that good, but I've had hundreds
of phone calls and letters and the like over
the years from people who will admit to having
some sort of what to me is a garden variety psychic experience, but they worried that
they were going crazy.
The fact that I as a professor as something of an authority figure can say, no, no, no,
that doesn't necessarily mean you're going crazy, right?
That's the kind of thing that happens to the
majority of people actually, except they never
talk about it, so they think it's really weird
and worry about it, and it has a name like
telepathy or clairvoyance or something like
that, and it doesn't mean you're necessarily
going crazy.
You should still be discreet who you talk to
about it because there are a lot of prejudiced
people out there who get excited about it, and most of those people have been greatly
relieved by five minutes of conversation that way.
A few, I think, were crazy.
I mean, they really needed some mental health
just because whether you're mentally ill or
mentally normal has nothing to do with
whether or not you have psychic experiences.
They happen to everybody.
Well, I do believe there's some research suggesting
that amongst the people who report more spontaneous
psychic experiences, they also report a greater incidence of early childhood abuse.
That's certainly been the case for some people
who've turned out to be quite psychic later
in life also, I'm thinking of Eileen Garrett,
for instance, had an extremely lonely and
persecuted kind of childhood, so the only
people she could play with were her so-called
imaginary playmates and whatnot, and yeah, that happens with a lot of people.
So there may be a relationship with imaginary
playmates being a kind of doorway into a psychic
realm.
And some people are lucky enough to take these
unusual things and use them as an opening
or as a growth challenge or something like
that, but a lot of people just suffer because
they're being told it's crazy.
Well, a couple of interesting directions we could take here.
I think it's worth mentioning since you brought up the name of Eileen Garrett.
She's considered one of the great mediums and psychics of an earlier era.
She's the founder of the Parapsychology Foundation.
You knew her personally.
Oh, yes.
When I went to college, I went to MIT, I was
going to be an engineer, and that put me in
Boston.
And there was the Exeter Street Theater nearby
in Boston that showed a lot of foreign films,
which was far out in that day, but also it was
owned by a couple of ladies who were spiritualists,
and they brought spiritualists and parapsychologists,
spiritual teachers and the like, in to give
lectures.
And I started going to those, and one of them was Eileen Garrett.
And I'm the kind of student that's lecturers
love, because I have questions and ask interesting
things.
So pretty soon I was being invited back to
tea afterwards with the speakers and met Mrs.
Garrett that way, and she was something I'd never known anybody else like her.
She did a lot to promote the acceptance of psychic functioning through her foundation.
I don't know, actually.
She certainly helped a lot of researchers by giving them small grants so they could
actually get started on research.
She gave me my first grant to do some research
in parapsychology, using hypnosis to try to
see if people could have out-of-the-body experiences, and it was amazing.
She gave me a $100 grant, which was a fortune
to me back then, so I could buy a tape recorder
and stuff.
And at the end of the grant, I was writing
up the report, and I told her I had something
like $5.50 left over, should I send it back?
And she said, no, keep the change.
Grants aren't like that anymore.
Well, it's interesting that a lot of that early parapsychology research actually, in
effect, funded by a woman who was a psychic.
Yes.
And she, herself, was also a very successful
businesswoman, probably one of the early feminists,
making it quite clear women could do just fine here.
And a publishing company.
And her foundation still exists.
I've known her daughter and her granddaughter.
Her granddaughter, Lisette, still runs the foundation.
And I was just talking with her recently on how important it is to have an organization
that got continuity over the years, and it doesn't have much money to give to people,
but a little small grants here and there can
be the things that trigger people off to start
them on a research career.
But another way to look at the fear of Psy
is how it influences not just the researchers
and people who are having psychic experiences,
but the skeptics as well, the irrational scoffers.
The pseudo-skeptics.
Yes.
Yes.
As I've said before, I like the idea of
skeptics because skeptic is an honorable role.
It means you're looking at the current explanation
of something and you don't think it's very
good.
You're curious and you'd like to see a better
explanation, so you help search for the truth.
But the people who call themselves skeptics
with respect to parapsychology now, in almost
all cases, they're not interested in helping to look for the truth.
They already know the truth, which is that
parapsychological stuff can't possibly happen,
so they attack the research.
It's like they're defending a religious orthodoxy
against heresy, but trying to pretend that
they're being scientific and rational.
I'm very disappointed in the skeptics.
I'm a skeptic in a sense that I don't think our explanations about most things are very
good.
I'm all for finding other ones, but that means
I have to take a chance on some of the ideas
because I think I know the truth about it wrong.
So it seems to me it's reasonable for a psychologist
such as yourself to begin to question the
motives of these skeptics, or not their
conscious motives, but their unconscious motives.
Yes.
I'd very much like to do that because many of
these pseudoskeptics are highly intelligent
people and many of them are scientists in some other area of science, but they don't
follow the rules of science.
If I think somebody's research is coming to the wrong conclusions, I try to see how the
research could be improved, not contact funding
agencies to stop funding these people or attacking
the people.
One of the primary examples happened when I was still very new in this field.
There was an article on science.
Now, science was and still is one of the most
prestigious scientific journals in the world.
If you publish something in there, it's a big deal.
There was an article on science in the supernatural
by a chemist, I don't know why chemists should
know about this, but his basic conclusion was
no intelligent person can read the evidence
for extrasensory perception and doubt that it exists.
Price was his name as I recall.
Yes, George Price, comma, but since we know it is impossible, we must conclude all this
evidence is due to error and fraud.
Wow, that's religious dogmatism.
That's not science.
What in the world was that doing in there?
But that was an attitude that was very commonplace and is still too commonplace.
Still common and on the internet in
particular, it's like they're armies of trolls.
They often post comments on these interviews
and I keep them there if they're polite, but
often they're very rude comments and I delete them.
When somebody first told me that somebody
published a biographical note for me on Wikipedia,
I thought, oh, really?
So naturally I looked it up and it was all
right, it had been copied from something I'd
posted by and large and once in a while I checked it and it kept getting changed.
So that innocent things that happened in my career now took on a sinister thing.
I taught at the University of Nevada for a year as a distinguished visiting professor
and they wanted me to be interested in staying
on, but no, I had other commitments, but they
described it as if I'd been asked to leave, just little things like that.
From Machiavellian point of view, some of
these pseudo-skeptics are very good at pushing
their case like debaters who winning is the only thing, not the truth.
Well one of the foremost skeptics, the late Martin Gardner, wrote an autobiographical
note of his life and pointed out that he was
raised in a fundamentalist Christian family
where he learned to fear the devil, be afraid
of the devil, and then he became enlightened
and he realized that what he needed to fear was
what he called the rising tide of superstition.
But it's as if he transferred all that emotion
of fearing the devil to now fearing the rising
tide of superstition, not very different really.
And when he was first making that kind of change, psychology in general still didn't
have much of an idea of emotional intelligence,
which thank God we're starting to get.
So a person can be quite brilliant intellectually,
but their emotions take over and distort their
things.
You know, Gurdjieff talked about the emotional
brain is faster than the intellectual brain.
Now we know the neurology of that.
It's like sensory signals to your senses come
in and they have to go through several neural
relays before they get to your consciousness,
each one taking a little bit of time.
But the path splits into two junctions very
quickly and the shorter path goes to the old
emotional brain.
So the old emotional brain might pick up on a situation before the intellect even knows
something is happening and say, uh-oh, scary, threatening, red alert.
And by the time the intellectual brain starts
getting the message, you're already all up
tight and ready to run or fight or something like that.
And your rational mind is just totally distorted.
You're saying something very important here about the human condition, not just about
psi and parapsychology, that we are very emotional creatures.
And it turns out that talking about the emotional
brain being faster is one of the most useful
things I've ever taught to students because,
you know, when we're too emotionally, we tend
to blame ourselves, you know, why can't I control it, how can I be?
When you find out that we're hardwired to be faster on the emotions, that gives you
more of an opportunity to say, okay, the more
primitive part of my brain caught me up, but
let me try and relax instead of lashing out
or something like that and give this a little
more conscious intellectual thought.
Not that emotion should be suppressed, but
we've got to have a balance between intellect,
emotion, body intelligence, stuff like that, as the emotional brain just is...
Its philosophy was expressed in the old
westerns, shoot first and ask questions later.
That's a good way to put it.
And it's laughable, but it creates an awful
lot of useless suffering, suffering that could
have been avoided if somebody had paused a couple of seconds to think about something.
And with regard to our discipline of parapsychology,
I think we have a situation today where you
have large numbers of people who are afraid for religious reasons.
Psychic phenomenon is real, they believe, but
it's the work of the devil, must be avoided.
And then you get large numbers of people who are kind of the inverse of that.
They think that psychic phenomenon doesn't exist, but we must be afraid of the rising
tide of superstition, and a tiny little segment,
one or two percent of the population, kind
of in the middle, who are saying, let's look
at it scientifically and see what science
might have to say about this.
Unfortunately, I think it's smaller than one or two percent, right?
You're sitting with a foremost exponent of it here, and I don't have many people I can
talk to about this.
You know, I've tried to talk to some religious
people, and in some ways, they're more harsh
rejectionists than the people who say that
scientifically they're rejecting psychic phenomena,
because they already know the truth in their particular religion.
And to question it is some kind of heresy that has to be defended against.
Well, I do think, Charlie, from my perspective,
doing this video series, and we have hundreds
of thousands of views on these videos, that
there's a growing segment of the population,
you could call them the cultural creatives or
some sort of a rebirth of a kind of secular
spirituality or Gnosticism, that that segment of the population is growing.
And I plead with them to make me a liar for that last statement, that the percentage is
smaller than one or two percent.
I mean, we can be rational about this, you know?
I think it's possible to, for instance, be faced
with a situation and say, well, my spiritual
beliefs say it's got to be like so and so, and
I realize I'm very attached to those particular
beliefs, and my motivation for being attached to them is good.
But am I really that smart?
Am I really so smart that I cannot actually look more closely at what's actually going
on and even consider other possibilities?
I mean, I think I can envision a kind of experimental
spirituality someday, where we say, yeah,
important things are happening, let's explore
the range of what's happened, and let's explore
what the consequences of them are.
You know, I mean dogmatic fundamentalism has a
lot of consequences that are extremely negative,
whereas an open-minded spirituality can have
a lot of positive consequences, as well as
being so wishy-washy that it doesn't mean anything.
So there's a balance to be learned between spiritual principles that you want to stick
to, but being open to learning something new.
I think, though, there's also some deeper issues.
We've talked about some of the irrational fears,
but there's also, I think, a psychological
dynamic.
As somebody opens up to psychic functioning,
there are questions about, is my ego going
to disappear?
Am I going to vanish myself as aâ€¦
While other spiritual traditions talk about how incredibly hard it is to make that ego
vanish.
They do, but there's also a fear associated with that.
Yeah.
Yeah.
So let me drop this to a deeper level here, talk about where I'm coming from on this.
In a conventional sense, I'm primarily a scientific
person, but from the inside, I think of myself
primarily as a spiritual seeker.
That doesn't mean I have all sorts of absolute truths that I can work from.
But I basically work from the premise that there is an intelligence in the universe.
I usually don't call it God because that gets
things too excited, but we don't have any
other really good words for it.
There's an intelligence, a compassion, and so forth.
The childhood idea that was given me that we're made in God's image, and presumably
God is intelligent, so by using our intelligence, we're actually praising God.
But I understand also that we're talking about
very powerful stuff, as some people experience.
It's not just gentle, gentle, there, there, everything is fine, it's all right.
Things are immense.
Could be much more than a little synchronicity here and there.
So there is a legitimate concern for it may be too much, and we have to deal with that
somehow.
We have to separate it from the irrational fears that somebody else is going to hex me
or something like that, but as long as we just kind of squish the whole subject down
and try to make it go away, that's not a way to handle it, it doesn't work.
You, for example, have talked about an exercise
you sometimes give to your students, saying
I have a pill here, let's conclude with that story.
I gave a lecture once for the American Society
for Psychical Research in New York City, and
big turnout, and afterwards they had a reception
for me at headquarters, a lot of parapsychologists,
people who had devoted their careers to studying
ESP and things like that at great cost themselves.
And I mentioned in a little off-the-cuff talk
afterwards that sometimes I thought I was
afraid of psychic phenomena that got weird, and I asked did anybody else ever have that
problem and nobody had, and I thought, well,
maybe I'm kind of neurotic that way, but out
of 30 or 40 people here in the room, I said,
no, no, come on, you know, nobody raised the
hand, and so I quickly devised this exercise,
look, little belief experiment, I've got a
pill in my pocket, I'm from California, okay, if
you take this pill, you will become telepathic
and know the thoughts and feelings of anybody
within 100 yards of you, and you'll only have
to take the pill once because it's a permanent change.
Now, how many want the pill?
Nobody said anything.
I said, how many want the pill?
So this philosophical discussion broke out about very abstract things, and I said, no,
how many want the pill, and finally I shouted at them, how many want the pill?
Nobody wants the pill.
That's very interesting compared to the abstract philosophy.
There's a lot of hesitancy and fear about becoming very psychic, and I've since done
this in more systematic ways with various
groups and had them write down their reasons.
Would I become responsible if I found somebody was suicidal near me?
Would I be driven nuts by the thoughts of all these people?
Maybe there's good reasons we're generally not psychic.
Well, it seems as if the nervous system itself is a filter.
Yes.
It keeps things out largely, and one of the
things that we all protect ourselves against,
I believe, is the pain in the world and the suffering of other people.
It could be overwhelming if we let it all in.
So we let just enough in that we can handle, usually.
The other day my daughter was over and talking
to my wife and I, and she started talking
about this horrible world event, and after a minute I told her, I don't want to talk
about this because it makes me really depressed
and there's nothing I can do about it, so
let's not talk about it.
She kept right on talking, and I asked again,
could we not, and she kept right on talking.
So I said, okay, I'm going to go in the other
room and do something for a few minutes, and
I walked out calmly.
They thought I was so horrible.
I said, you know, it's pain I can't do anything about.
It'll just make me depressed, and that doesn't
make me capable of doing anything more helpful,
but yet, you know, by not buying it, oh, it's complicated.
I don't have answers, but we have to look at the problem more if we want to hope to
have any, to find any answers.
Charlie Tart, thank you for sharing this discussion with me.
I think this is a very important issue.
Yeah, too important.
Thank you for being with me.
Thank you for the opportunity, Jeff, to bring it up.
And thank you for being with us.
And remember to make a liar out of me.
